verses.text: When Saul returned from pursuing the Philistines, he was told, 'Look! David is in the wilderness of En-Gedi.'
verses.comment: Kept original location name 'En-Gedi' as in Hebrew text.

verses.text: Then Saul took three thousand chosen men from all Israel and went to look for David and his men near the rocks of the wild goats.
verses.comment: The phrase 'rocks of the wild goats' is literal from Hebrew 'rocks of the ibexes.'

verses.text: He came to the sheepfolds beside the road, where there was a cave, and Saul went in to relieve himself. Meanwhile, David and his men were staying in the innermost parts of the cave.
verses.comment: 'Relieve himself' is a literal rendering of the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: David’s men said to him, 'This is the day the LORD spoke of when he said to you,
verses.comment: Reflects the Hebrew; David's men reference a general promise, not a direct quote from earlier text.

verses.text: Afterward, David’s heart troubled him because he had cut off a corner of Saul’s robe.
verses.comment: 'Heart troubled him' is a literal translation of 'David's heart struck him.'

verses.text: He said to his men, 'The LORD forbid that I should do this thing to my lord, the LORD’s anointed, to stretch out my hand against him, for he is the LORD’s anointed.'
verses.comment: 'LORD’s anointed' is kept as in Hebrew ('Mashiach YHWH').

verses.text: So David restrained his men with words and did not let them rise against Saul. And Saul got up from the cave and went on his way.
verses.comment: Literally, 'tore apart'—meaning restrained—his men with words.

verses.text: Afterward, David also got up and went out of the cave and called after Saul, 'My lord the king!' When Saul looked behind him, David bowed with his face to the ground and did obeisance.
verses.comment: Kept literal 'did obeisance,' i.e., prostrated himself in respect.

verses.text: David said to Saul, 'Why do you listen to men who say,
verses.comment: Reflects original Hebrew; the quote is from fears expressed earlier in Saul’s reign.

verses.text: Today your eyes have seen how the LORD gave you into my hand in the cave. Some urged me to kill you, but I spared you. I said, “I will not stretch out my hand against my lord, for he is the LORD’s anointed.”
verses.comment: Direct restatement of Hebrew dialogue.

verses.text: See, my father, look at the corner of your robe in my hand! For I cut off the corner of your robe and did not kill you. Recognize and see that there is no evil or rebellion in my hand. I have not sinned against you, yet you hunt my life to take it.
verses.comment: David calls Saul 'my father' to reflect his respect and family tie.

verses.text: May the LORD judge between me and you, and may the LORD avenge me on you, but my hand shall not be against you.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: As the proverb of the ancients says, “From the wicked comes wickedness.” But my hand shall not be against you.
verses.comment: Ancient proverb is retained; no specific citation, as in original.

verses.text: After whom has the king of Israel come out? Whom are you pursuing? A dead dog, a single flea!
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'dead dog' and 'flea' are Hebrew idioms for insignificance.

verses.text: May the LORD therefore be judge, and decide between me and you; and may he see and plead my cause, and deliver me out of your hand.
verses.comment: "Plead my cause"—literal; Hebrew courtroom imagery.

verses.text: When David finished saying these words to Saul, Saul said, “Is this your voice, my son David?” And Saul lifted up his voice and wept.
verses.comment: Literal; the emotional response is retained.

verses.text: He said to David, “You are more righteous than I, for you have repaid me good, though I have repaid you evil.”
verses.comment: Saul's acknowledgement retained; 'repaid' is literal.

verses.text: You have just shown today how you have dealt well with me, since the LORD gave me into your hand and you did not kill me.
verses.comment: Explicit connection between God’s action and David’s mercy.

verses.text: For if a man finds his enemy, will he let him go away safely? So may the LORD reward you with good for what you have done to me this day.
verses.comment: Saul recognizes David's mercy as rare.

verses.text: Now, look, I know that you will certainly be king, and that the kingdom of Israel will be established in your hand.
verses.comment: Saul’s prophecy is kept literal from Hebrew.

verses.text: Now swear to me by the LORD that you will not cut off my descendants after me, and that you will not destroy my name from my father’s house.
verses.comment: 'Not cut off my descendants'—literal phrasing from Hebrew.

verses.text: So David swore to Saul. Then Saul went home, but David and his men went up to the stronghold.
verses.comment: The final locations retained as in Hebrew; 'stronghold' refers to David's mountain fortress.
